anchor.surface_text: Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. V. Viswanatha Sastri, K. O. fain and B. P. Maheshwari, for the petitioners. Bishan Narain, Sukumar Ghose and P. D. Menon, for the respondent.

They have filed the present petition under Art. 32, challenging the validity of two numberifications dated January- 15, 1958, and December 2, 1960, issued by the Central Government under s. 7 1  of the employees Provident Funds Act. 1952

issued by the Central Government under s. 7 1  of the employees Provident Funds Act. 1952 hereinafter referred to as ,the Act. It will be companyvenient to first set out the relevant statutory provisions bearing on the question.

anchor.surface_text: employees Provident Funds Act. 1952 hereinafter referred to as ,the Act. It will be companyvenient to first set out the relevant statutory provisions bearing on the question. The Act was passed for the purpose ofproviding for the institution of Provident Funds for the employees in factories and other establishments.

concepts.unlisted_description: The principal statute for provident funds in factories and establishments

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 of the Act, which deals with this matter is as follows - Employees Provident Fund Schemes.- 1  The Central Government may, by numberification in the Official Gazette, frame a Scheme to be called the employees Provident Fund Scheme for the establishment of provident funds under this act

concepts.interpretation: Empowers Central Government to frame provident fund schemes applicable to specified establishments, prospectively or retrospectively.

concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine under Art.19(6) assessing if restrictions on business rights are reasonable

issues.text: whether the two notifications dated January 15, 1958 and December 2, 1960, are constitutional

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the petitioners have filed the present petition, raising the question of the constitutionality of the two notifications dated January 15, 1958 and December 2,1960. They contend that they throw a heavy burden on their business and cannot, in consequence, be upheld as reasonable

issues.text: whether the notifications dated January 15, 1958, and December 2, 1960, throw a heavy burden on business and cannot be upheld as reasonable restriction within Art. 19(6) infringing Art. 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: They contend that they throw a heavy burden on their business and cannot, in consequence, be upheld as reasonable restriction within Art. 19 6  and must be struck down as infringing Art. 19 1  g  of the Constitution. The respondents on the other hand maintain that they are beneficent legislation

issues.text: whether the obligation of the employer to contribute to the provident fund is capable of performance as regards contract labour given lack of knowledge of wages and eligibility

anchor.surface_text: Now the argument of the petitioners is that the obligation of the employer to contribute every month to the provident fund an amount equal to six and a quarter per cent. of the wages and dearness allowance of the employee is incapable of performance as the principal employer is not in a position to know what wages had been agreed between the contractor and his employees

issues.text: whether the right given to the principal employer under Para 32 to deduct the member's contribution from wages is capable of exercise as against contract labour

anchor.surface_text: A more serious objection to the extension of the Scheme of 1952 to workmen employed through contractors is that the right given to the principal employer under Par 32 is incapable of exercise as against them. Under Par 30 the whole of the provident fund, being 12-1/2 per cent. of the wages ad dearness allowance has, to be paid

issues.text: whether the scheme operates unfairly and results in discrimination between employers of contract labour and direct labour such that it is not a reasonable restriction under Art. 19(6)

anchor.surface_text: It operates unfairly and harshly on persons who employ contract labour and it further results in discrimination between those who employ contract labour and those who employ direct labour. The Scheme therefore cannot be said to be reasonable and must be struck down as not falling within the protection afforded by Art. 19  6
